glossary.definition: A defined sequence of tasks and phases for performance management processes
A specific action or step within a workflow that must be completed
A stage in a workflow containing one or more tasks
Pattern for repeating workflows (e.g., annual, quarterly)

business_rules: Workflows must have defined phases and tasks
Tasks must be completed in sequence within a phase
Phases must be completed in order before workflow can advance
Tasks can have dependencies on other tasks
Workflow completion requires all phases and tasks to be finished
Tasks can be assigned to specific participants or roles
Workflow automation can trigger notifications and phase transitions
Workflow recurrence creates new instances based on schedule
Workflow status must be tracked and visible to participants
Workflow can be paused, resumed, or cancelled with proper authorization
invariants: Workflow must have at least one phase
Phase must have at least one task
Task dependencies must not create cycles
Workflow status must be valid (pending, in_progress, completed, cancelled)
Task assignment must be to valid participant or role
edge_cases: Task assignee is unavailable - system allows reassignment or extension of deadline
Task dependency is not met - system blocks dependent task, sends notification
Workflow deadline is missed - system flags overdue, sends escalation notification
Workflow is cancelled mid-execution - system handles partial completion, maintains history
Recurring workflow instance conflicts - system detects conflict, adjusts schedule or creates exception
Task is completed out of sequence - system flags violation, may allow or require correction
Workflow phase is skipped - system prevents skip unless authorized override is provided
Workflow automation fails - system logs error, sends alert, may require manual intervention
compliance_requirements: Workflow execution must be logged for audit purposes
Task completions must be timestamped and attributed
Workflow changes must be documented with reason
Workflow history must be retained for compliance
Workflow automation must be tested and validated
user_journeys: HR creates performance workflow - defines phases and tasks, workflow template is available
System creates workflow instance - assigns participants, activates first phase, sends notifications
Participant completes assigned task - marks task complete, system validates and advances if phase complete
System automates phase transition - when all tasks complete, system advances to next phase
Workflow completes - all phases finished, workflow is closed, completion notification is sent
Recurring workflow creates new instance - based on schedule, new instance is created and started
acceptance_criteria_suggestions: Given workflow creation, when phases and tasks are defined, then workflow template is created and available
Given workflow instance, when participants are assigned, then instance is created and first phase is activated
Given task completion, when task is marked complete, then system validates and advances phase if all tasks done
Given phase completion, when all tasks are complete, then system advances to next phase automatically
Given workflow completion, when all phases are finished, then workflow is closed and completion is communicated
open_questions: What are the specific workflow types? (evaluation? objective setting? performance review?)
How are task dependencies handled? (blocking? non-blocking? warnings?)
What is the workflow recurrence pattern? (annual? quarterly? custom?)
How are workflow deadlines enforced? (automatic escalation? notifications? penalties?)
What is the process for workflow modifications? (can active workflows be modified?)
How are workflow automation rules configured? (triggers? conditions? actions?)
assumptions: Workflows consist of phases containing tasks
Tasks must be completed in sequence within phases
Phases must be completed in order
Workflow automation can trigger phase transitions
Workflow recurrence creates new instances based on schedule
